III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff
Title
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of youth
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth went AWOL 3-4 days ago from the facility. Other youth at
the facility were physically assaulting this youth. Youth was
located and taken to the hospital.
Investigation Interviews:
On 09/18/2024 a voicemail message was left for Complainant
requesting a return call with any additional information regarding
the complaint.
The following interviews were completed onsite at Wolverine
Center on 09/19/2024, unless otherwise noted.
An interview was completed with Lead Supervisor. She was
advised of the special investigation allegations. She advised that
the current census for the facility is 11. She reported that Youth A
was placed at the facility on 8/14/24. He went AWOL frequently
during his stay and his bed was closed on 9/12/04 after going
AWOL on 09/11/2024. Lead supervisor denies any knowledge of
Youth A being beaten up by other youth. She confirmed
knowledge of some verbal disagreements between Youth A and
other youth, but nothing physical. Lead supervisor noted that
youth had complained that Youth A would engage in the use of
racial slurs to antagonize other youth. Lead Supervisor confirmed
that staff would redirect any name calling among youth. Lead
Supervisor denies knowledge of a time that staff failed to
intervene in situations involving Youth A or any youth at the
facility.
An interview was completed with Youth B. He confirmed that he
was placed at the agency when Youth A was there. When asked
about his interactions with Youth A, he replied that he did not want
to speak and requested to leave the meeting.
An interview was completed with Youth C. He recalled Youth A
and confirmed that they were placed at the agency together. He
reported that he got along well with Youth A and denied that they
2

were ever in a fight or argument. He denied knowledge of any
fights between Youth A and other youth. Youth C reported that
Youth A was disrespectful to female staff and would often go
AWOL and blame others for him getting into trouble. Youth C
reported that staff would split youth up if there were
disagreements between them or if they were fighting. He denied
knowledge of any instance when staff failed to intervene.
An interview was held with Youth D. He denied specifically
remembering Youth A. He denied knowledge of staff failing to
intervene when youth are engaging in any type of inappropriate
behavior at the facility. He specifically indicated that staff are
engaged and provide supervision. He stated that they will
respond when there are issues.
An interview was held with Supervisor 1. She recalled Youth A
and mentioned that he would go AWOL from the facility. She
stated that staff would follow protocol and monitor the youth until
no longer in line of sight. She further reported that law
enforcement would be contacted, and a report made. She also
stated that all youth are discouraged from going AWOL and are
advised of the risks and safety concerns associated with leaving
the agency without permission. In addition, she stated that youth
are offered support and given other things to do to provide
structure in their day. She recalled that Youth A would tell staff
that he would AWOL because he wanted to go back home.
Supervisor 1 confirmed that Youth A was in a lot of altercations
with other youth. She reported that he came off as “racist” and
would call both staff and youth racial slurs, specifically “nigger”.
She recalled that Youth A stated he was not used to being around
“that many black people”. Supervisor 1 stated that staff would
always redirect Youth A when he was heard making any negative
statements or making any attempt to engage negatively with other
youth. She denied that she or any other staff refused to intervene
if youth were arguing or fighting. She reported that staff always
intervene and try to separate youth from each other to deescalate
situations.
An interview was held with Staff 1. He denied that he has ever
failed to intervene when youth in the program are not following
rules or guidelines. He denied knowledge of any youth fighting
and staff failing to intervene. He specifically indicated he was not
aware of any youth fighting or targeting Youth A. He
acknowledged that Youth A has gone AWOL and reported that
staff make attempts to discourage youth from going AWOL by
redirecting them and offering support to youth that are struggling
3

in the program. Staff 1 denied hearing Youth A use racial slurs
toward staff or other youth in the program.
On 09/19/2024 a telephone interview was completed with Chief
Administrator. She was advised of the allegation of the
investigation. She advised that Youth A would frequently AWOL
from the facility and made it very clear that he did not want to be in
the Detroit area and wanted to be placed in a facility near his
home town. Chief Administrator denied knowledge of staff failing
to intervene when youth are arguing or fighting with each other.
She specifically denied knowledge of any reports from Youth A
indicating that youth were fighting him, and staff failed to do
anything.
On 09/19/2024 a video interview was completed with Youth A.
He confirmed that he was previously placed at Wolverine Center
and stated he went AWOL from the facility and as a result he was
no longer at that facility. Youth A recalled having disagreements
with other youth in the program but denied being in any fights. He
confirmed that he would use racial slurs at the facility. He stated
that he used the word “nigger” but denied that it was ever directed
toward any specific youth or staff. When asked if staff would take
action if and when youth were fighting or not following program
rules and he responded yes. He indicated that some staff were
mean to him and called him names. He was unable to identify
specific staff that called him names. Youth A initially denied that
he told supervision or other staff about being called names but
later stated that he told staff, but they would not listen. He was
unable to identify a specific staff.
On 09/19/2024 a email correspondence was sent and received
from the assigned Foster Care Worker for Youth A. No additional
concerns were noted.
Documents reviewed:
Wolverine AWOL Policy: Staff will make efforts to verbally
redirect the truanting youth and will offer the youth support and
alternatives to truancy. If a non-supervising staff is available, they
will walk with the youth and continue to provide verbal support and
redirection encouraging the youth not to truant. Staff will
immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist Supervisor on duty
when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 minutes from loss of line
of sight (when youth is determined AWOL). The Youth Specialist
Supervisor will contact the Lead Supervisor and Program
Management who will provide oversight for incident management.
The youth specialist supervisor will ensure law enforcement is
4

notified immediately (no more than 5 minutes from when youth is
determined AWOL). Staff will notify law enforcement and program
director. Client specifics will be provided to Law enforcement and
an IR will be completed.
When a Client Returns:
If the client returns to the site, the appropriate supervising agency
must be contacted for authorization to re-admit the client and
remove the client’s truancy status. All parties notified of truancy
must also be notified at the time of return.
WHS Incident Reports Involving Youth A –
A total of 20 incident reports involving Youth A were provided for
review.

8/26/24 - Youth A went AWOL

9/9/24 - Youth A went AWOL/Return from AWOL
9/10/24 - Youth A went AWOL/Return from AWOL
9/11/24 - Youth A went AWOL
Wolverine Supervision Policy: Indicates the primary job of all
staff is to maintain adequate coverage and Line of Sight of all
clients. Specifically, this means that the clients are never left
unattended for any amount of time and that you can view all
behavior of the client you supervise. This ensures that client in
your care will not be abused; sexually, emotionally and/or
physically.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with licensing rule 4126. Both staff and youth were
interviewed and there was no evidence to support that Wolverine
staff failed to provide for the needs and protection of youth in the
program. Specifically, during the interview of Youth A, he denied
that staff failed to intervene during any issues or concerns
between youth in the program.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
